Mapstr - Explore the world

Mapstr is a storage and a synchronization service that let users save and share they favorite places. Standing at the intersection of the address book and the map provider, it is used to safely store personalized geopoints from local places to fully custom places.

Used by over +200 thousands of users across the world, Mapstr aims to build the default app to bookmark places, a platform at the in-between of a commodity tool and an private social network.

My role within the team as a UX Designer, was to help increase user acquisition, drive the engagement in order to build-up our community, through the design and delivery of both inclusive and accessible interface solutions. Directly related to the CEO, I led and mentored a team of 6 engineers, worked the end-to-end process from design research to product iterations, and provided documentation from prototypes to GUI specifications. Retrospective (succes metrics?)

Design a system

Mapstrâ€™s old logotype and app icon had gone practically unchanged since the companyâ€™s creation and it was more than time for a refresh. The weird color, the hash icon plus the lack of typographic effort â€” using a default system font â€” clearly made the brand system feel outdated.

Component kit

Building a platform

Mapstrâ€™s goal is to build the default platform to create, collect, and share places everywhere around the world. The first problem we met was how to build trust from our users, how to inform them that the platform is secure and private by design? Each steps of the process required a deep focus on giving users the best way to access, control and manage their data â€” dealing with rather personal inputs, to create a trustworthy platform.

Component kit

Connected to your apps

As a platform, we needed to communicate with apps and external data providers.

I designed and shipped a module that let users import places from different APIs â€” parsing retrieved geopoints, and converting them into places with valid content informations. Local source files such as .csv or .klm were also supported.

To build up the platform experience, users could also browse recent deleted data through a backup storage settings page.

Designed for the inner circle

When we introduced the User Accounts feature, we knew that we reached a milestone step. Enabling our users to interact within the app had a huge impact on acquisition â€” which at that moment, was the bottom line lever to our companyâ€™s business growth.

Based on research outcomes, we first defined a user model architecture, then I was in charge of the complete UX workflow, from the sign-up journey to the design, test phases and implementation of every user related features.

It was very challenging to deal with projects involving designing for user privacy along with inputing growth processes â€” creating a platform at the in-between of a commodity tool and an private social network.
